title: ext4 semantics: Implement inode read (ffs-inode) from disk image
description:
Goal: read an ext4 inode by inode number and return a typed struct with enough info for getattr + extent mapping.

Dependencies:
- ext4 inode location math helper
- ext4 inode parsing that respects inode_size
- BlockDevice reads

Deliverables:
- ffs-inode: read_inode(inode_no) -> Ext4Inode (or higher-level Inode)
- Handle inode numbers starting at 1; validate bounds.
- Map ParseError to FfsError with context.

Acceptance:
- Fixture test reads a known inode and matches expected mode/size/flags.
- Used by path lookup + getattr in later tasks.

title: Docs: Align parser error taxonomy (ParseError vs FfsError)
description:
Problem: COMPREHENSIVE_SPEC describes some parser failures as returning FfsError::Format/Corruption, but the current design uses ffs-types::ParseError for pure parsing (ffs-ondisk) and maps to FfsError at the orchestration boundary (ffs-core / ffs-ext4 / ffs-btrfs).

Goal: document the layering explicitly:
- ffs-ondisk is pure and returns ParseError
- ffs-core converts ParseError to FfsError for user-facing surfaces (CLI/FUSE)
- checksum verification errors choose a stable representation (ParseError::InvalidField vs a dedicated variant)

Acceptance:
- Spec sections that mention parser error returns match the actual crate boundaries.
- No doc requires ffs-ondisk to depend on ffs-error (unless we intentionally change architecture and implement it).

title: Repair: Implement RaptorQ encode/decode workflow + decode proof
description:
Goal: given a set of missing/corrupted blocks in a block group, reconstruct them using repair symbols.

Deliverables:
- Use asupersync RaptorQ codec to generate symbols and attempt decode.
- Produce a DecodeProof artifact: which symbols used, success/failure, residual error.
- Integrate with MVCC commit seq: repair applies to a specific snapshot/version.

Acceptance:
- Fault injection fixture: corrupt N blocks, decode succeeds when redundancy is sufficient.
- Decode failures are explainable (proof shows why insufficient).

title: ffs-types: Add missing canonical newtypes (BlockSize, ByteOffset, GroupNumber, DeviceId, Generation, ...)
description:
Goal: make ffs-types the single canonical home for cross-crate identifiers and basic arithmetic invariants.

Why: without strong newtypes we will silently mix units (bytes vs blocks, logical vs physical, ext4 group vs btrfs objectid) and ship corruption bugs.

Deliverables (minimum set):
- BlockSize(u32): must be power-of-two; ext4 v1 supports 1024/2048/4096 only.
- ByteOffset(u64): byte offsets on ByteDevice; checked add/sub/mul helpers.
- GroupNumber(u32): ext4 block group index.
- DeviceId(u64) or u128: stable id for multi-device future; for now single-device only.
- Generation(u64): btrfs generation / ext4 generation boundary type.
- LogicalBlock(BlockNumber) vs PhysicalBlock(BlockNumber) wrappers if we decide they are distinct.

Acceptance:
- All added newtypes have documented invariants + constructors that enforce them.
- Existing code in ffs-ondisk/ffs-block/ffs-core is updated to use these types where it improves correctness.

title: Repair: Define repair symbol format + storage strategy (per block group)
description:
Goal: decide where repair symbols live and how they are versioned.

Deliverables:
- Symbol format: header (block id, commit seq, checksum), payload.
- Storage strategy options:
  - reserved metadata area (native-mode)
  - sidecar file/log
  - embedded in unused ext4 structures (only if clean-room + safe)
- Versioning: how symbols relate to MVCC commit sequences.

Acceptance:
- Strategy is compatible with "drop-in mount ext4 image" goals (no silent mutation unless explicitly in FrankenFS-native mode).
- Recovery after crash is defined.

title: Epic: ext4 Read-Only MVP (lookup/readdir/read)
description:
Deliver a minimal ext4 read-only stack sufficient for harness and FUSE read-only mount.

Acceptance:
- Can read root inode (2), list root directory, resolve a simple path, and read file bytes.
- All behavior covered by fixtures/harness tests.

title: MVCC: Implement MVCC-aware block device wrapper (read snapshot -> version or base)
description:
Goal: make block reads/writes snapshot-aware.

Deliverables:
- Define MVCCBlockDevice (or similar) that wraps an underlying BlockDevice plus a version store.
- Read path: read_visible(block, snapshot) else fall back to base device read_block().
- Write path: stage_write(block, bytes) into the current transaction.
- Ensure block buffers are block_size aligned and validated.

Acceptance:
- Unit tests demonstrate snapshot visibility with base+versioned reads.
- No global locks on read path; concurrency model documented.

title: ext4: Implement feature flag decoding + validation policy (compat/ro_compat/incompat)
description:
Goal: represent ext4 feature flags in a way that is (1) easy to validate, (2) easy to print for UX, and (3) safe against unknown bits.

Deliverables:
- Define bitflags (or equivalent) for compat/ro_compat/incompat.
- Implement decode helpers that produce:
  - required bits missing?
  - explicitly rejected bits present?
  - unknown incompatible bits present?
- v1 mount policy:
  - require FILETYPE + EXTENTS
  - block sizes limited to 1K/2K/4K
  - reject compression/encrypt/casefold/inline-data, etc.

Acceptance:
- validate_v1() returns ParseError with stable field+reason.
- Tests cover: required bits missing, unknown incompat bit, known rejected bit, allowed-but-nonrequired bits.

title: FUSE: Define MVCC snapshot/transaction policy for FUSE operations
description:
Goal: decide how MVCC integrates with the kernel request model.

Questions:
- Does each FUSE op run at a single snapshot (read-only), or do we start a transaction per open()/release()?
- How do we handle readdir+lookup consistency?

Deliverables:
- A documented policy in COMPREHENSIVE_SPEC.
- Implementation hooks in ffs-fuse to acquire snapshot/tx per request.

Acceptance:
- Concurrency tests show consistent reads under concurrent writers (once writes exist).
- Policy is simple enough to reason about and test.

title: Track: btrfs On-Disk Parsing + Mapping (ffs-ondisk)
description: Implement btrfs superblock parsing, sys_chunk_array bootstrap mapping, single-device logical->physical mapping, and basic B-tree node/item parsing for read-only discovery.\n\nAcceptance: can open a btrfs image, validate superblock, map a logical address via sys_chunk, and iterate root tree items without panics; all guarded by fixtures.

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
btrfs bootstrap is different from ext4: you must parse sys_chunk_array to map logical->physical before you can even read the trees.

Early wins:
- parse superblock + sys_chunk
- map root/chunk_root
- parse nodes and walk root tree (read-only)

Multi-device and RAID profiles remain explicitly excluded until read-only parity is solid.

title: ffs-types: Finalize InodeNumber strategy (ext4 u32 vs btrfs u64)
description:
Context: ext4 stores inode numbers as u32; btrfs uses u64 objectids. The code currently standardizes on InodeNumber(u64) in ffs-types.

Goal: make the representation choice explicit and safe:
- keep InodeNumber(u64) canonical, but add per-format wrappers (Ext4InodeNumber(u32), BtrfsObjectId(u64)) OR
- switch to an enum/typed wrapper that prevents mixing domains.

Deliverables:
- Chosen representation documented in ffs-types docs + COMPREHENSIVE_SPEC.
- Conversion functions at parsing boundaries.
- Tests proving no silent truncation or sign/width bugs.

Acceptance:
- No crate invents its own inode/objectid types.
- Public APIs do not require callers to guess whether a u64 is ext4 or btrfs.

title: btrfs: Implement node parse helpers (internal + leaf, item table bounds)
description:
Goal: provide safe parsing primitives for btrfs tree nodes.

Deliverables:
- Parse node header (already exists) and validate bytenr, nritems, level.
- Parse item table for:
  - leaf nodes (items point to payload within block)
  - internal nodes (items point to child block pointers)
- Provide iterators that yield keys + (offset,size) or key + child pointer.

Acceptance:
- Unit tests cover malformed item tables (overlaps, out-of-bounds offsets, overflow).
- Works on at least one real btrfs node fixture.

title: ext4 semantics: Implement FsOps adapter over ext4 context (ffs-core/ffs-ext4)
description:
Goal: provide an implementation of the internal FsOps trait for ext4, backed by parsing + block I/O.

Deliverables:
- Ext4Fs struct: holds Ext4Context + BlockDevice + caches.
- Implement getattr/lookup/readdir/read by calling ffs-inode/ffs-dir/ffs-extent helpers.

Acceptance:
- Harness can instantiate Ext4Fs and run end-to-end tests (no FUSE required).
- FUSE layer can mount by delegating to this implementation.

title: btrfs: Implement checksum verification hooks (superblock + nodes) [phased]
description:
Future task: verify btrfs checksums according to csum_type.

Deliverables:
- Implement superblock checksum verification.
- Implement node/header checksum verification.
- Support at least CRC32C first; extend as needed.

Acceptance:
- Flipped-bit fixture fails verification and is reported by scrub.

title: MVCC: Design persistence for versioned blocks (COW log / version store)
description:
Goal: move MVCC from in-memory-only to durable versioned storage.

Deliverables:
- Choose a version store strategy:
  - append-only log of (block, commit_seq, bytes)
  - or a separate COW file with mapping table
- Define crash consistency (fsync points, recovery on restart).
- Define GC/pruning strategy and watermark semantics.

Acceptance:
- A concrete design exists in COMPREHENSIVE_SPEC + PROPOSED_ARCHITECTURE.
- We can replay the version store to reconstruct the latest snapshot after restart.

title: Docs: Reconcile ext4/btrfs scope + phased support statements
description:
Goal: make sure every doc says the same thing about what FrankenFS V1 supports and what is explicitly excluded/phased.

Must be consistent across: COMPREHENSIVE_SPEC, PLAN, README, FEATURE_PARITY.

Scope items to pin down:
- ext4 v1: supports 1K/2K/4K block sizes; requires extents+filetype; read-only mount first; journaling replay and writes later.
- btrfs: phased; single-device sys_chunk mapping and read-only discovery first; no multi-device/RAID/compression initially.

Acceptance:
- There is one canonical exclusions list and it is referenced everywhere.
- Any test corpus/harness fixtures do not contradict exclusions.

title: MVCC: Implement SSI conflict detection (phased, correctness-first)
description:
Goal: detect and prevent write skew / dangerous structures beyond FCW.

Deliverables:
- Define read_set/write_set tracking strategy with version info (not just BlockNumber).
- Implement rw-antidependency tracking and dangerous-structure detection per SSI literature.
- Provide an escape hatch: run SSI only for write transactions (read txns should be cheap).

Acceptance:
- A formal model section in the spec that matches code.
- Tests cover a known write-skew scenario that FCW allows but SSI rejects.

title: Cleanup: Delete bootstrap temp files (.spec_*.md) [REQUIRES EXPLICIT USER PERMISSION]
description:
Rule: DO NOT delete any file without explicit written user permission (AGENTS.md Rule 1).

Scope:
- Remove leftover bootstrap concatenation artifacts like .spec_*.md (currently at least .spec_10_11.md exists).

Acceptance:
- Only proceed after user provides explicit written permission naming the files/pattern.
- Record the permission text and exact command(s) executed in the final response when it happens.

title: Track: MVCC Engine (ffs-mvcc)
description: Implement block-level MVCC: snapshot reads, versioned writes, commit/abort semantics, and (phased) conflict detection (SSI-style) suitable for filesystem workloads.\n\nAcceptance: deterministic correctness under asupersync lab runtime (reproducible schedules), explicit invariants + tests, and integration with ffs-block for versioned block storage. Must be designed so FUSE operations can run concurrently without global locks.

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
MVCC is the core FrankenFS differentiator.

We start with FCW (simple, testable), then evolve toward SSI only where necessary.
Key integration points:
- MVCC-aware block reads: (snapshot -> version or base)
- Durable version store design
- Deterministic concurrency tests

This track must remain mathematically defensible and heavily tested.

title: CLI: Implement mount subcommand (ffs-cli mount <image> <mountpoint>)
description:
Goal: provide the primary entry point for users: mount an ext4 image via FUSE.

Deliverables:
- Add CLI parsing for mount args + options (read-only, allow-other, etc).
- Use ffs-core OpenFs API to open/validate image.
- Construct ffs-fuse Filesystem + start fuser mount loop.

Acceptance:
- Manual E2E: mount fixture image read-only and run ls/stat/cat.
- Errors are user-friendly and map to correct errno/log messages.

title: TUI: Minimal dashboard (cache/MVCC/repair metrics) via ftui [phased]
description:
Goal: provide a live view of internal state for debugging and demos.

Deliverables:
- A ftui-based screen that shows:
  - cache hit/miss, p value
  - mvcc commit seq, open txns
  - repair overhead + recent scrub events

Acceptance:
- Can run against a local mount or harness run and update periodically.

title: Epic: ext4 Advanced Semantics (htree, symlink, xattr, permissions)
description:
Follow-on work to reach stronger ext4 parity beyond the MVP.

Scope examples:
- htree indexed dirs
- symlinks
- xattrs
- permission bits and ownership mapping details

Acceptance:
- Each feature has fixtures and at least one conformance comparison against kernel behavior.

title: ext4: Implement group descriptor checksum verification hooks (metadata_csum)
description:
Goal: prepare for ext4 metadata checksum verification (CRC32C) when the filesystem uses metadata_csum.

Deliverables:
- Determine checksum algorithm and seed for group descriptors (from legacy ext4 code) including how group number participates.
- Add a function: verify_group_desc_checksum(desc_bytes, group_nr, superblock) -> Result<()>.
- If metadata_csum is not enabled, skip verification.

Acceptance:
- Unit tests: known-good descriptor passes; flipped-bit fails.
- Error type is stable and mapped correctly for user-facing surfaces.

title: ffs-block: Concurrency design for cache (sharding + no I/O under lock)
description:
Goal: make sure cache remains safe and fast under many concurrent FUSE operations.

Deliverables:
- Decide locking strategy (single Mutex vs sharded) and document it.
- Ensure we never do disk I/O while holding a global cache lock.
- Add a concurrency stress test under asupersync lab runtime (deterministic schedule) or standard threads with timeouts.

Acceptance:
- Stress test does not deadlock.
- Contention is measured (optional) and stays reasonable under synthetic load.

title: FUSE: Implement read-only ext4 ops (getattr/lookup/readdir/open/read)
description:
Goal: mount a supported ext4 image read-only and run basic workloads (ls/stat/cat).

Deliverables:
- Map fuser callbacks to FsOps: getattr, lookup, readdir, read.
- Correct file type + mode bits in replies.
- Correct errno mapping for not found / not dir / permission.

Acceptance:
- Manual E2E: mount fixture image and run ls -la, stat, cat on a known file.
- Integration test (if feasible) exercises a mounted instance in CI or as a local script.

title: ext4: Implement CRC32C checksum verification (superblock + inode + dir tail)
description:
Goal: verify ext4 metadata checksums when metadata_csum feature is enabled.

Deliverables:
- Add crc32c dependency (or equivalent) in appropriate crate.
- Implement verify_superblock_checksum() (note: superblock checksum rules differ from group desc).
- Implement inode checksum verification hook (phased).
- Implement directory block tail checksum verification hook (phased).

Acceptance:
- Unit tests: checksum passes on known-good fixture bytes, fails on flipped bit.
- Scrub pipeline can reuse these hooks to detect corruption.

title: Track: Filesystem Semantics (alloc, btree, extent, inode, dir, xattr, journal)
description: Implement the actual filesystem metadata/data operations (initially ext4 read-only path) on top of on-disk parsing + block I/O. This is where we reach meaningful parity beyond 'can parse a superblock'.\n\nAcceptance: can resolve paths, read directory entries, read file data (extents), and report metadata via harness; later phases add writes + journal/MVCC integration.

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
This track is where parsing turns into an actual filesystem.

We split into:
- ext4 Read-Only MVP (lookup/readdir/read) to unlock FUSE mounting and meaningful parity.
- ext4 Advanced (htree, symlink, xattr, etc).
- Write Path epic (alloc/journal/MVCC integration) for later.

All semantics work must be fixture-backed and routed through a minimal FsOps trait.

title: ext4 semantics: Implement path lookup (linear scan) for name -> inode
description:
Goal: resolve paths like /a/b/c by walking directory inodes.

Deliverables:
- ffs-dir: lookup(parent_inode, name) -> inode_no.
- Use linear scan over parsed dir entries first (htree phased).
- Handle special entries: "." and "..".

Acceptance:
- Fixture test resolves a few known paths.
- Errors are correct: NotFound vs NotDirectory vs NameTooLong.

title: ext4: Expand superblock parsing toward full layout (ffs-ondisk)
description:
Goal: parse the ext4 superblock fields needed for mount validation and downstream math (group desc locations, inode table, features, checksums).

Deliverables (incremental):
- Parse additional core fields: s_log_cluster_size, s_blocks_per_group, s_inodes_per_group, s_inode_size, s_desc_size, s_feature_* full, s_uuid, s_checksum_seed (if present), s_checksum.
- Provide a structured representation for feature flags (bitflags or typed wrapper).
- Add tests that compare parsed values against known bytes (fixtures).

Acceptance:
- No panics on malformed data (ParseError only).
- validate_v1() can be implemented purely from parsed fields.
- Fixture-based test covers at least one real ext4 image superblock dump.

title: ext4: Implement directory entry parsing (ext4_dir_entry_2)
description:
Goal: parse ext4 directory blocks into entries for name lookup and readdir.

Deliverables:
- Parse ext4_dir_entry_2: inode(u32), rec_len(u16), name_len(u8), file_type(u8), name bytes.
- Validate rec_len alignment and bounds within the directory block.
- Expose an iterator that walks entries in a block without allocations where possible.

Acceptance:
- Unit tests cover: empty entry, last entry, invalid rec_len (zero, overflow), name_len > rec_len.
- Fixture test parses a real directory block and matches debugfs listing.

title: Docs Gate: Re-audit docs for contradictions + produce current Errata list
description:
Purpose: re-check the current versions of COMPREHENSIVE_SPEC_FOR_FRANKENFS_V1.md / PROPOSED_ARCHITECTURE.md / PLAN_TO_PORT_FRANKENFS_TO_RUST.md / FEATURE_PARITY.md / AGENTS.md / README.md for internal contradictions and doc-vs-code drift.

Why: implementation is unsafe if normative types/traits/crate boundaries disagree across docs. This task produces the *current* (not historical) Errata list used to drive follow-up fixes.

Deliverables:
- A short Errata section added to COMPREHENSIVE_SPEC_FOR_FRANKENFS_V1.md (or a dedicated doc) listing each mismatch with file+anchor and the intended resolution.
- A mechanical checklist for future audits (rg patterns + invariants to verify).

Acceptance:
- Errata list is complete enough that every other docs-fix issue below can reference it.
- No 'unknown unknowns' in the top-level normative contracts (types, errors, core traits, crate map).

title: Track: Image I/O + Block Cache (ffs-block)
description: Provide the Cx-aware ByteDevice/BlockDevice abstraction plus metadata cache. This is the performance-critical hot path for parsing, MVCC, and repair.\n\nAcceptance: safe superblock reads by fixed offsets, block-aligned geometry validation, deterministic cancellation behavior via &Cx checkpoints, and an ARC-like metadata cache with fixtures + benchmarks. Write-back is phased; start with read-cache correctness.

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
ffs-block is the hot path.

Rules of engagement:
- Every public I/O method takes &Cx for cancellation.
- No disk I/O while holding global locks.
- Cache design must be benchmarked only after fixtures prove correctness.

This track feeds parsing, MVCC, repair, and FUSE latency.

title: CLI: Switch to clap-based structured CLI (inspect/mount/fsck/stats)
description:
Goal: move from ad-hoc env::args parsing to a structured CLI.

Deliverables:
- Use clap derive.
- Subcommands: inspect, mount, fsck/scrub, parity, stats.
- Ensure --json output is stable for automation.

Acceptance:
- Help output is clear and matches README.
- Existing inspect behavior preserved.

title: ffs-core: Implement ParseError -> FfsError mapping with context
description:
Goal: when pure parsers return ParseError, higher layers must convert to FfsError with enough context to be actionable.

Deliverables:
- A function (or trait) in ffs-core: map_parse_error(context, ParseError) -> FfsError.
- Context includes: which structure (ext4 superblock vs group desc vs inode), what offset/group/inode number, etc.
- Ensure mapping preserves details without leaking huge byte dumps.

Acceptance:
- CLI inspect prints useful errors.
- FUSE mount returns stable errno plus a clear log message.

title: ext4 semantics: Implement readdir (ffs-dir) via dir_entry_2 parsing
description:
Goal: list directory entries for a directory inode.

Deliverables:
- ffs-dir: read_dir(inode_no) -> Vec<DirEntry> or iterator.
- Read directory data blocks via extent mapping (or direct blocks for very small dirs if needed).
- Parse each directory block using ext4_dir_entry_2 parser.

Acceptance:
- Fixture test: root directory (inode 2) entries match expected set.
- Handles malformed entries defensively (skips or errors with context, per policy).

title: Harness: Define Linux-kernel reference capture strategy (ext4/btrfs)
description:
Goal: prove behavioral parity by comparing FrankenFS outputs against a trusted reference.

Options:
- Use kernel tools (dumpe2fs/debugfs/btrfs inspect-internal) to produce golden JSON.
- Or mount images via kernel FS driver and observe syscalls/metadata.

Deliverables:
- Choose which behaviors are compared (superblock fields, inode stat, directory listing, extent mapping).
- Define a reproducible capture pipeline that produces versioned golden outputs.

Acceptance:
- At least one end-to-end conformance test exists that compares FrankenFS output to kernel-derived golden output.

title: Docs: Canonicalize normative trait definitions (BlockDevice/MVCC/Repair)
description:
Goal: ensure each major trait contract is defined once (normative), with stable signatures (including &Cx requirements) and stable semantic notes.

Scope:
- ffs-block traits: ByteDevice/BlockDevice (or equivalent)
- MVCC public traits (begin read tx, begin write tx, versioned read/write, commit/abort)
- Repair interfaces (scrub report, symbol generation, decode proof)

Deliverables:
- Choose canonical trait locations (PROPOSED_ARCHITECTURE + COMPREHENSIVE_SPEC).
- Remove or mark 'illustrative' any alternate trait signatures that diverge.
- Ensure &asupersync::Cx usage is consistent (no ambient authority).

Acceptance:
- No doc section defines a second incompatible trait signature.
- The crate that owns each trait is explicit (no 'phantom home crate').

title: ffs-error: Decide mount-validation error variants (UnsupportedFeature/UnsupportedBlockSize/etc)
description:
Context: mount validation can fail because of unsupported feature bits, block sizes, or incompatible on-disk geometry.

Question: do we represent these as:
- ParseError::InvalidField (and map to FfsError::Format), OR
- dedicated FfsError variants (UnsupportedFeature, UnsupportedBlockSize, InvalidGeometry), OR
- an intermediate MountValidationError used by ffs-core.

Deliverables:
- Chosen approach documented.
- Error mapping yields correct errno (EINVAL vs EOPNOTSUPP) for FUSE and CLI.

Acceptance:
- ext4 validate_v1() failures are surfaced with stable errors and good UX.
- Docs/spec do not list non-existent FfsError variants.

title: ext4 semantics: Implement file read (cat) using extent mapping
description:
Goal: read regular file data by mapping logical blocks to physical blocks and reading from BlockDevice.

Deliverables:
- ffs-inode or ffs-core: read_file(inode_no, offset,len) -> bytes.
- Support partial-block reads.
- Handle holes/unwritten extents conservatively (return zeroes or error, per policy).

Acceptance:
- Fixture test reads a known file and matches golden bytes.
- Works through the same path used by FUSE read().

title: Repair: Extract FrankenSQLite RaptorQ approach and adapt to filesystem blocks
description:
Goal: reuse proven strategy from /dp/frankensqlite for fountain-code-based self-healing, but adapted to ext4/btrfs block groups and filesystem workloads.

Deliverables:
- Summarize the key FrankenSQLite design choices: symbol placement, overhead tuning, decode proofs, ledgering.
- Identify what changes for filesystems: block group boundaries, metadata vs data, read/write patterns.
- Update COMPREHENSIVE_SPEC repair section with an explicit design derived from this extraction.

Acceptance:
- We can explain exactly how a corrupted block is detected and which symbols are used to repair it.
- The design includes tunable parameters and an expected-loss justification (not ad-hoc thresholds).

title: MVCC: Specify API + invariants (TxnId/CommitSeq/Snapshot) and phase plan (FCW -> SSI)
description:
Goal: make MVCC semantics unambiguous before integrating with filesystem operations.

Deliverables:
- Document: what a Snapshot means (visibility window), when it is taken, and how it is used for reads.
- Document: transaction lifecycle (begin -> stage writes -> commit/abort) and what is allowed concurrently.
- Phase plan:
  - Phase A: First-committer-wins (FCW) conflict check at commit.
  - Phase B: Add optional SSI tracking (read sets + rw-antidependencies) where needed.

Acceptance:
- ffs-mvcc public API is stable enough that ffs-fuse can build on it.
- There is a simple correctness proof sketch for FCW and a roadmap for SSI.

title: Semantics: Define a minimal VFS operations trait for FUSE/harness
description:
Goal: define the internal interface FUSE and harness call.

Deliverables:
- A trait (e.g. FsOps) with methods needed for read-only mount:
  - getattr(inode)
  - lookup(parent,name)
  - readdir(inode)
  - read(inode,offset,len)
- Types for file attributes and directory entries.

Acceptance:
- ffs-fuse can implement the fuser::Filesystem methods by delegating to this trait.
- ext4 implementation can live behind this interface (and later btrfs too).

title: Track: Performance Baselines + Regression Gates
description: Establish measurable performance goals and prevent regressions via baselines + profiling discipline (per extreme-software-optimization).\n\nAcceptance: (1) hyperfine baselines exist for key paths (detect/open/parse ext4 superblock+groupdesc, btrfs superblock+map), (2) benchmark harness exists for cache hot paths, (3) optimization PRs require before/after numbers + isomorphism proof + golden checksums.

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
Optimization is not a vibe.

We follow the loop:
- baseline (hyperfine)
- profile
- change one lever
- prove behavior unchanged (goldens + checksums)
- re-measure

This track exists to keep performance claims honest and regressions detectable.

title: btrfs: Expand superblock parsing (sys_chunk_array + validation)
description:
Goal: parse enough of btrfs superblock to bootstrap mapping without reading chunk tree yet.

Deliverables:
- Parse sys_chunk_array and sys_chunk_array_size fields.
- Add validation for sectorsize/nodesize/stripesize: non-zero, power-of-two where required, and sane bounds.
- Expose a helper to iterate sys_chunk_array entries.

Acceptance:
- Fixture-backed test: parse a real btrfs superblock and confirm sys_chunk_array size/contents are plausible.
- No panics on malformed input.

title: ext4: Implement superblock geometry validation (group/inode math sanity)
description:
Goal: validate ext4 geometry beyond magic+block size, so later helpers (inode table math, group desc iteration) are safe.

Deliverables:
- Validate blocks_per_group and inodes_per_group are non-zero and within sane bounds.
- Validate inode_size is supported (>=128, power-of-two-ish, and fits in block).
- Validate desc_size is supported (>=32, <= block size, and consistent with 64BIT feature).
- Validate first_data_block rules: for 1K blocks, first_data_block=1; for 2K/4K, typically 0 (document exact rule).
- Compute group_count and validate group desc table length fits in device.

Acceptance:
- validate_v1_geometry() (or equivalent) exists with unit tests for edge cases.
- No unchecked division by zero or overflow in downstream code.

title: Harness: Add btrfs fixtures for sys_chunk mapping + node parsing
description:
Goal: fixture-back btrfs mapping and node parsing work.

Deliverables:
- Add sparse fixtures for:
  - superblock with non-empty sys_chunk_array
  - at least 1 btrfs leaf node block (nodesize) with a few items
- Add harness helpers to parse and validate:
  - mapping of root/chunk_root logical addresses
  - leaf item table bounds

Acceptance:
- btrfs mapping + node parse tasks have fixtures that fail if bounds checks regress.
- Parity counts updated when coverage increases.

title: Harness: Add ext4 fixtures for group descriptors + inode parsing
description:
Goal: extend conformance/fixtures beyond superblock so new ext4 parsing work is fixture-backed.

Deliverables:
- Add sparse fixtures for:
  - at least 1 group descriptor (32-byte) and 1 group descriptor (64-byte)
  - at least 1 inode (with extents) and 1 directory inode
  - at least 1 directory block (dir_entry_2)
- Add harness validation helpers that parse these fixtures and assert key fields.

Acceptance:
- New ext4 parsing tasks (group desc, inode parse, dirent parse) have at least one fixture each.
- FEATURE_PARITY and ParityReport are updated in the same change when coverage increases.

title: Perf: Maintain scripts/benchmark.sh + add baselines for key paths
description:
Goal: keep a repeatable benchmark entry point as the CLI/harness evolves.

Deliverables:
- Update scripts/benchmark.sh when commands or binaries change.
- Add baselines for:
  - ffs-cli inspect <fixture>
  - ffs-core open/validate ext4
  - btrfs sys_chunk mapping (once implemented)

Acceptance:
- scripts/benchmark.sh runs successfully on a fresh checkout.
- Baselines are stable enough to detect regressions.

title: FrankenFS V1 Program (Spec -> Parity -> MVCC -> Self-Heal -> FUSE)
description:
Root epic for FrankenFS V1. Goal: a memory-safe, clean-room Rust filesystem that is mount-compatible with ext4 images (and later btrfs), but internally uses copy-on-write MVCC and self-healing durability.

This epic is CLOSED only when all track epics are closed (docs/spec integrity, ext4/btrfs on-disk parsing, I/O + caching, harness/conformance + benchmarks, MVCC, repair, FUSE mount surface, CLI/TUI, performance gates).

Non-negotiables (see AGENTS.md): no unsafe code, Rust 2024/nightly, no destructive commands, spec-first + conformance-first, keep FEATURE_PARITY current.

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
How To Use This Beads Graph (self-contained):

- Find actionable work: br ready --json
- Visualize dependencies: br dep tree <id>
- Never create cycles: br dep cycles (must be empty)
- After changing issues: br sync --flush-only (exports .beads/issues.jsonl)

Design doctrine (why this plan is structured into tracks):
- Spec-first + conformance-first: we do not trust line-by-line C translations. Each behavior needs fixtures/harness coverage.
- Most catastrophic filesystem bugs are unit/offset mismatches and unchecked arithmetic; foundations + parsing invariants are early epics.
- FUSE is a thin adapter: it should delegate to a minimal internal FsOps trait so correctness can be tested without mounting.
- MVCC + repair are treated as first-class tracks with explicit invariants and decision-theoretic policies (no magic thresholds).

Definition of Done for any implementation task:
- Implement the behavior
- Add fixture(s) or property tests
- Update FEATURE_PARITY + ffs-harness ParityReport in the same change
- Pass: cargo fmt --check, cargo check --all-targets, cargo clippy --all-targets -- -D warnings, cargo test --workspace

title: Track: ext4 On-Disk Parsing + Validation (ffs-ondisk)
description: Implement ext4 superblock/groupdesc/inode/extents parsing and v1 validation rules (1K/2K/4K only).\n\nAcceptance: fixture-backed parsing (no panics on malformed input), explicit incompat/ro_compat/compat feature handling, geometry validation, inode location math, and enough metadata decode to support read-only directory traversal in harness.

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
ext4 v1 support policy is intentionally narrow:
- Block sizes: 1K/2K/4K only.
- Required features: FILETYPE + EXTENTS.
- Unknown incompatible feature bits must fail validation.

This track exists to make ext4 parsing boring: bounded, checksum-aware, and fixture-backed.

title: Docs: Resolve layering contract (ffs-fuse / ffs-core / semantics boundaries)
description:
Goal: make crate boundaries unambiguous so implementation does not drift.

Decisions to document:
- ffs-fuse is a thin adapter over an internal FsOps trait.
- ffs-core owns open/detect/validate and constructs per-format contexts.
- semantics crates (ffs-inode/ffs-dir/ffs-extent/...) implement the actual operations.

Acceptance:
- PROPOSED_ARCHITECTURE.md + COMPREHENSIVE_SPEC agree on the layering and dependency direction.
- Cargo.toml dependency edges match the documented layering.

title: ext4 semantics: Implement xattr parsing + getxattr/listxattr [phased]
description:
Future task: support extended attributes.

Deliverables:
- Parse ext4 xattr header and entries (inline and block-based).
- Implement getxattr/listxattr semantics.

Acceptance:
- Fixture xattr values match kernel outputs.

title: Perf: Add criterion benches for cache hot paths + parsing loops
description:
Goal: measure the actual hotspots once correctness fixtures exist.

Deliverables:
- Criterion bench for:
  - ARC cache hit path
  - ARC cache miss path (no I/O in bench; use in-memory ByteDevice)
  - ext4 group desc iteration / inode read (once implemented)

Acceptance:
- Benches run in CI or at least locally with stable results.
- Bench outputs are used to drive targeted optimization work.

title: Docs: Reconcile crate map + dependency claims with Cargo workspace
description:
Goal: ensure every docs crate table/diagram matches Cargo.toml + crates/*/Cargo.toml reality (including phased dependencies like fuser).

Deliverables:
- COMPREHENSIVE_SPEC and PROPOSED_ARCHITECTURE crate lists reflect the 21-crate workspace (19 core + ffs-ext4/ffs-btrfs wrappers + ffs facade).
- Each crate description states: purpose, allowed deps, and which phase introduces it.
- Remove stale claims (e.g. crates that "depend on X" when they do not).

Acceptance:
- A reviewer can grep any crate name and find exactly one consistent description of its purpose and deps.
- No phantom crates remain except in historical notes that explicitly say they are phantom.

title: Docs: Resolve missing ARCHITECTURE.md / CONVENTIONS.md references
description:
Problem: PLAN_TO_PORT_FRANKENFS_TO_RUST.md references ARCHITECTURE.md and CONVENTIONS.md as if they exist, but they do not in this repo.

Options:
1) Create these docs with narrowly-scoped content:
- ARCHITECTURE.md: crate topology + key invariants + dataflow diagrams (thin, points to COMPREHENSIVE_SPEC + PROPOSED_ARCHITECTURE).
- CONVENTIONS.md: code style rules, Definition of Done, checklists (fmt/check/clippy/test), parity update protocol.
2) Remove references entirely and ensure existing docs cover the intent.

Acceptance:
- No references to non-existent files remain.
- If files are created, they are referenced as the canonical location for the promised content and kept small (no duplicate spec).

title: Docs: Align errno mapping (Cancelled EINTR vs ECANCELED, etc.)
description:
Problem: COMPREHENSIVE_SPEC_FOR_FRANKENFS_V1.md currently documents Cancelled -> EINTR, but crates/ffs-error/src/lib.rs maps Cancelled -> ECANCELED.

Goal: choose the canonical errno semantics for each FfsError variant (especially cancellation) and ensure:
- ffs-error::to_errno() matches that choice
- docs tables match that choice
- FUSE behavior uses it consistently

Acceptance:
- A single authoritative errno mapping table exists (prefer ffs-error docs or code comment) and docs reference it.
- COMPREHENSIVE_SPEC + PLAN + PROPOSED_ARCHITECTURE do not contradict the code.
- We document the rationale (EINTR vs ECANCELED) in one place.

title: ffs-error: Decide Cancelled errno semantics and update to_errno()
description:
Context: cancellation propagates via asupersync::Cx::checkpoint(). For FUSE, cancellation can be represented as EINTR (interrupted) or ECANCELED (explicit cancellation).

Goal: choose one policy and implement it in crates/ffs-error/src/lib.rs::to_errno(), and align docs accordingly.

Acceptance:
- Cancelled maps to the chosen errno everywhere.
- We document the rationale (kernel/VFS expectations, operator experience, retry semantics).

title: MVCC: Version GC/pruning semantics + watermark API
description:
Goal: prevent unbounded growth of version chains while preserving snapshot correctness.

Deliverables:
- Define watermark: the oldest snapshot that must remain readable.
- Implement prune_versions_older_than with clear semantics (keep at least one version per block).
- Integrate with version store persistence design.

Acceptance:
- Tests show: pruning does not break reads at snapshots >= watermark.
- Memory usage remains bounded in a long-running simulation.

title: ffs-core: Define OpenFs API (detect -> parse -> validate -> context)
description:
Goal: provide a single entry point for higher layers (CLI, harness, FUSE) to open a filesystem image.

Deliverables:
- Define types: FilesystemKind, OpenFs (or Ext4Context/BtrfsContext), OpenOptions.
- OpenFs contains: parsed superblock, computed geometry, block device handle, and any derived constants.
- API shape should make it impossible to forget validation (open() should validate by default).

Acceptance:
- ffs-cli and ffs-harness use this API exclusively (no ad-hoc probing).
- Error messages include enough context for UX (which validation failed).

title: ffs-core: Implement btrfs open/validate pipeline (phased, read-only)
description:
Goal: open a btrfs image via ffs-block + ffs-ondisk, validate superblock fields, and produce a BtrfsContext suitable for read-only discovery.

Deliverables:
- Read btrfs superblock region via ffs-block helper.
- Parse BtrfsSuperblock and validate nodesize/sectorsize.
- Build sys_chunk logical->physical mapper for single-device images.
- Provide a method to read the root tree node via mapping.

Acceptance:
- Can open a fixture btrfs image and enumerate a few root-tree items (using the btrfs track primitives).
- Failures return structured errors (not just UnsupportedImage).

title: ffs-core: Implement ext4 open/validate pipeline on ByteDevice
description:
Goal: open an ext4 image via ffs-block + ffs-ondisk, validate v1 constraints, and produce an Ext4Context used by higher layers.

Deliverables:
- Read ext4 superblock region via ffs-block helper.
- Parse Ext4Superblock and call validate_v1 + geometry validation.
- Construct a BlockDevice using the ext4 block_size.
- Compute group_count and any derived constants needed for later reads.

Acceptance:
- Unit tests: synthetic images + failure cases.
- Fixture test: open a real ext4 image and print key fields (via harness/CLI) without panics.

title: Track: Self-Healing Durability (ffs-repair + RaptorQ)
description: Implement scrub + repair workflows using fountain-code repair symbols (RaptorQ) at block-group granularity, inspired by FrankenSQLite.\n\nAcceptance: (1) detect corruption via checksums/invariants, (2) decide repair policy via explicit expected-loss model, (3) generate/store repair symbols with bounded overhead, (4) demonstrate recovery in harness via fault-injection fixtures.

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
Self-healing must be explainable.

We will not ship "magic" repair heuristics:
- detect corruption via checksums + invariants
- decide redundancy/repair via expected-loss model
- record decode proofs so we can audit why a repair succeeded/failed

This is explicitly patterned after FrankenSQLite, adapted to block groups.

title: Harness: Define fixture generation workflow (sparse fixtures + real images)
description:
Goal: make it easy to add fixtures for new parsing/semantics features without ad-hoc manual bytes.

Deliverables:
- Document fixture formats used in conformance/fixtures (sparse JSON today).
- Add a generator approach:
  - option A: produce sparse fixtures from real images by extracting only relevant byte ranges
  - option B: maintain small handcrafted fixtures for unit tests, and use real images for E2E

Acceptance:
- Adding a new fixture is a repeatable recipe (commands + expected outputs) documented in-repo.
- Fixtures are small enough to live in git and stable across platforms.

title: ext4: Expand inode parsing (timestamps, uid/gid, flags, extent/inline fields)
description:
Goal: parse enough of ext4 inode to support read-only semantics (stat + extent mapping + directory traversal).

Deliverables:
- Parse core inode fields: mode, uid/gid (low/high), size, atime/ctime/mtime/crtime, links, flags, generation, blocks.
- Respect inode_size (128 vs 256) and avoid assuming fixed offsets exist if inode smaller.
- Parse i_block area for extent header and inline extents.

Acceptance:
- Fixture tests compare against debugfs/dumpe2fs for at least a few inodes.
- Parser never panics; InsufficientData is returned for short slices.
- Extent parsing from inode is wired via parse_inode_extent_tree().

title: ext4: Implement HTree directory index parsing (dx_root/dx_entry) [phased]
description:
Future-facing task: implement parsing of ext4 hashed directory indexes (htree) for fast lookup in large directories.

Deliverables:
- Parse dx_root, dx_entry tables, and hash seed.
- Implement lookup(name) -> candidate leaf blocks.
- Verify hash algorithm matches kernel (TEA/half-MD4 depending on feature).

Acceptance:
- Works on a fixture directory with htree enabled.
- Verified against debugfs for lookup paths.

Note: small directories can be handled by linear scan; htree becomes required for parity on large dirs.

title: Track: FUSE Mount Surface (ffs-fuse)
description: Implement the Linux userspace mount interface via the fuser crate. This is the external contract: kernel VFS calls -> FrankenFS operations.\n\nAcceptance: can mount a supported ext4 image read-only via FUSE and run basic operations (ls/stat/cat) with correct errno mappings, using ffs-core to open/validate and ffs-mvcc to provide snapshot semantics.

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
FUSE should stay thin and stupid.

Design intent:
- ffs-fuse delegates to internal FsOps.
- Errors map via FfsError::to_errno.
- MVCC snapshot policy for requests is explicit and testable.

This keeps correctness testable without needing to mount during unit tests.

title: Track: Core Orchestration (ffs-core)
description: Own the high-level open/detect/validate orchestration. ffs-core should be the single entry point for: detect filesystem kind, parse superblock, validate v1 constraints, and construct per-format mount contexts for FUSE/harness.\n\nAcceptance: callers (CLI, harness, FUSE) use ffs-core (not ad-hoc probing). All detection uses fixed-offset reads and returns structured errors suitable for UX + errno.

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
ffs-core is the integration choke-point.

It should be the only place that:
- detects filesystem flavor
- opens devices
- validates v1 constraints
- builds mount contexts

All UX surfaces (CLI/harness/FUSE) should call ffs-core, not re-implement probing.

title: CLI: Replace Cx::for_testing() with production context acquisition
description:
Problem: ffs-cli currently uses Cx::for_testing() as a placeholder.

Goal: decide how production binaries acquire a Cx (cancellation, deadlines, tracing) and implement it.

Deliverables:
- A helper in ffs-core or ffs-cli to build a Cx for CLI invocations.
- Ensure cancellation behavior is testable (SIGINT -> cancel).

Acceptance:
- inspect and mount use the same Cx acquisition.
- No test-only APIs are used in production code paths.

title: ffs-block: Implement ARC metadata cache (read-only first)
description:
Goal: implement an ARC-like cache wrapper for block reads to reduce random I/O during metadata-heavy operations.

Scope (v1):
- Cache read_block() results (BlockNumber -> BlockBuf).
- ARC lists: T1/T2 + ghost lists B1/B2; adaptive parameter p.
- No write-back yet; writes either bypass or invalidate.

Key design questions to answer explicitly:
- Cache key: BlockNumber only, or (BlockNumber, CommitSeq/Version) for MVCC? (If MVCC needs versioned cache, design now.)
- Concurrency: avoid holding cache locks while doing disk I/O.

Acceptance:
- Unit tests cover core ARC transitions (hits/misses/evictions) with deterministic sequences.
- No deadlocks; no I/O under locks.
- Benchmarks show cache improves repeated metadata reads on fixture images.

title: Track: Docs + Spec Integrity (No Drift, No Phantom Contracts)
description: Make the documentation set internally consistent and consistent with the workspace. This track exists because implementation cannot proceed safely if types/traits/crate boundaries are contradictory across COMPREHENSIVE_SPEC/PROPOSED_ARCHITECTURE/PLAN/FEATURE_PARITY.\n\nAcceptance: (1) cross-doc audit returns no Critical/High contradictions, (2) all referenced crates/files exist, (3) canonical glossary/trait locations are unambiguous, (4) any intentional divergence is explicitly labeled 'illustrative' vs 'normative'.

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
Initial known doc/code drift to include in the Errata pass (starting point, not exhaustive):

- Cancelled errno mapping mismatch: COMPREHENSIVE_SPEC currently says EINTR; crates/ffs-error maps to ECANCELED.
- Parser error taxonomy needs explicit layering: ffs-ondisk returns ParseError today; user-facing layers return FfsError.
- PLAN references ARCHITECTURE.md and CONVENTIONS.md which do not exist; decide create vs remove.

Audit output should focus on: normative type/trait single-source-of-truth, crate map accuracy vs Cargo.toml, and eliminating phantom contracts/phantom crates.

title: Harness: Establish parity accounting protocol (FEATURE_PARITY.md <-> ParityReport)
description:
Goal: ensure we never lose track of what is implemented.

Deliverables:
- Define the canonical source of parity totals (FEATURE_PARITY.md) and the canonical source of parity current counts (ffs-harness ParityReport::current).
- Add a lightweight check/test that FEATURE_PARITY.md numbers match the harness report (or the harness reads the file).

Acceptance:
- Any PR that changes implemented functionality updates parity in the same change.
- No more hand-edited divergent numbers.

title: Docs: Align toolchain/MSRV statements (Rust 2024, nightly toolchain)
description:
Goal: ensure docs do not state an impossible MSRV.

Context:
- Rust edition 2024 requires Rust >= 1.85.
- The repo uses rust-toolchain.toml for nightly.

Deliverables:
- Ensure PLAN/README/COMPREHENSIVE_SPEC consistently state the toolchain policy.
- If we claim an MSRV, it must be technically compatible with edition + dependencies.

Acceptance:
- No doc claims a Rust version that cannot compile the workspace.

title: ext4: Implement inode location math helper (inode -> table block + offset)
description:
Goal: given (inode_number, superblock fields, group desc), compute where the inode bytes live on disk.

Deliverables:
- Pure helper: inode_number -> (group, index_in_group).
- Use group desc inode_table pointer and inode_size to compute:
  - table_start_block
  - inode_byte_offset_from_table_start
  - absolute byte offset on device
- Handle ext4 inode numbering rules (inode numbers start at 1; 0 invalid).

Acceptance:
- Unit tests for boundary inodes: 1, inodes_per_group, inodes_per_group+1, last inode.
- Overflow/invalid inputs produce ParseError/FfsError (no panics).
- Helper is used by higher-level inode read code (ffs-inode later).

title: Repair: Expected-loss policy for redundancy + repair (alien-artifact bar)
description:
Goal: choose repair symbol overhead and repair actions using an explicit decision-theoretic model (not heuristics).

Deliverables:
- Define loss model: corruption cost vs redundancy overhead cost.
- Maintain posterior over corruption rate (Beta prior) or richer model as needed.
- Decision rule: choose overhead that minimizes expected loss.
- Integrate with ffs-core DurabilityAutopilot (or refactor it into ffs-repair if it belongs there).

Acceptance:
- Policy produces explainable outputs (posterior rate + chosen overhead + expected loss).
- Harness includes a test that the policy reacts sensibly when corruption events are observed.

title: Repair: Implement scrub pipeline (detect corruption signals)
description:
Goal: detect corrupted blocks/metadata reliably.

Deliverables:
- Define signals:
  - ext4 metadata_csum / btrfs csum verification failures
  - structural invariant violations (bounds, tree ordering)
- Implement ScrubReport with per-block findings and severity.

Acceptance:
- Harness can inject corruption (flip bit) and scrub reports it deterministically.
- Scrub does not panic on corrupted data; it returns structured findings.

title: Track: Harness + Conformance + Parity Accounting (ffs-harness)
description: Build the proof system: fixture generation, comparisons against Linux behavior where applicable, parity reporting, and regression gates.\n\nAcceptance: every implemented behavior has (1) a fixture or property test, (2) a harness test that exercises it end-to-end, (3) FEATURE_PARITY + harness parity numbers updated in the same change. Benchmarks are added only after fixtures exist.

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
ffs-harness is the proof engine.

Rules:
- every new behavior needs fixtures or properties
- parity numbers must match FEATURE_PARITY.md
- only optimize after correctness vectors exist

Without this track, progress becomes vibes instead of verified parity.

title: ffs-block: Cache metrics + instrumentation surface
description:
Goal: expose cache behavior to harness/CLI/TUI so performance work is evidence-based.

Deliverables:
- CacheMetrics struct: hit/miss counts, evictions, current list sizes, p value.
- A cheap snapshot method to read metrics without heavy locks.
- Optional tracing hooks gated behind feature flag.

Acceptance:
- Metrics can be queried from ffs-core and printed by ffs-cli inspect.
- Metrics are used by benchmarks to assert improvements are real (not noise).

title: Track: CLI + TUI (ffs-cli + ffs-tui)
description: Provide operator tooling: CLI subcommands (inspect/info/fsck/mount), and a frankentui-based dashboard to observe cache/MVCC/repair stats.\n\nAcceptance: CLI is the primary UX for harness + debugging; TUI can attach to a running mount to show internal metrics. Both must be deterministic/testable and use ffs-core as the integration surface.

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
Operator UX track.

CLI is the debugging and automation surface:
- stable JSON output options
- mount/fsck workflows
- parity/stats commands

TUI is phased and depends on metrics surfaces from cache/MVCC/repair.

title: ffs-block: Plan write-back cache + dirty tracking (phased)
description:
Future-facing task: define how cached writes become durable.

Deliverables:
- DirtyTracker design: which blocks are dirty, ordering constraints, flush scheduling.
- Interaction with MVCC: versioned writes vs overwriting.
- Failure/cancellation semantics (fsync, flush on close, etc).

Acceptance:
- A concrete design exists in docs/spec before any write-back code is added.

title: MVCC: Deterministic concurrency tests (asupersync lab runtime)
description:
Goal: make MVCC correctness testable under controlled schedules.

Deliverables:
- Add tests that run transactions under deterministic scheduling (asupersync lab runtime) and explore interleavings.
- Encode invariants: snapshot visibility, FCW conflicts, no lost updates.
- Add at least one regression test for a known anomaly pattern (write skew) once SSI is introduced.

Acceptance:
- Tests are deterministic and non-flaky.
- A small set of schedules is enough to reproduce bugs reliably.

title: Docs: Canonicalize normative type definitions (single source + cross-links)
description:
Goal: ensure every core type has ONE normative definition and every other doc reference links to it (no divergent signatures/field types).

Scope (must be covered):
- ffs-types: BlockNumber, BlockSize (to add), ByteOffset (to add), InodeNumber (u64 canonical), TxnId, CommitSeq, Snapshot, GroupNumber (to add), DeviceId (to add), Generation (to add)
- Parsing errors: ParseError and mapping boundary to FfsError
- Any MVCC identifiers (TxnId/CommitSeq) must not fork into TxId/Lsn synonyms unless explicitly aliased.

Deliverables:
- Choose canonical source locations (prefer ffs-types + COMPREHENSIVE_SPEC glossary).
- Replace all other duplicate definitions with 'see <canonical section>'.

Acceptance:
- rg finds no conflicting alternative definitions of these names in docs.
- Any intentional alias is documented once (e.g. 'TxnId and TxId are the same; we standardize on TxnId').

title: btrfs: Implement single-device logical->physical mapping (sys_chunk only)
description:
Goal: given a logical bytenr, map it to (device_id, physical_bytenr) using only the sys_chunk_array bootstrap data.

Scope (v1):
- single-device images only
- only mapping via sys_chunk_array (enough to read the chunk tree/root tree)

Deliverables:
- Parse chunk items from sys_chunk_array.
- Implement map(logical) -> physical (with bounds checking).

Acceptance:
- Fixture test: pick known logical addresses (superblock.root, superblock.chunk_root) and verify mapping lands inside the device.
- No panics; invalid mapping returns ParseError/Format.

title: CLI: Implement fsck/scrub command (read-only integrity scan)
description:
Goal: provide an operator-visible integrity scan that runs scrub and prints a report.

Deliverables:
- ffs-cli fsck/scrub <image> [--json]
- Use ffs-repair scrub pipeline to produce ScrubReport.

Acceptance:
- On a clean fixture image: report is empty or low severity.
- On a corrupted fixture: report includes the corrupted block and reason.

title: btrfs: Implement initial read-only tree-walk (root -> items iterator)
description:
Goal: given a btrfs superblock and a logical->physical mapper, implement a minimal tree traversal that can enumerate items in a tree (starting with root tree).

Deliverables:
- Read root node at superblock.root (using mapper + BlockDevice).
- Descend internal nodes by key ranges until leaf.
- Iterate leaf items and expose (BtrfsKey, payload slice) to higher layers.

Acceptance:
- Can enumerate some items from a real btrfs image (fixture) without panics.
- Traversal is deterministic and fully bounds-checked.

title: ffs-error: Define canonical error taxonomy + mapping boundaries
description:
Goal: make error handling consistent across layers:
- ffs-ondisk returns ParseError (pure parsing)
- ffs-core/ffs-fuse/ffs-cli return FfsError (user-facing)

Deliverables:
- Document the mapping from ParseError -> FfsError (which variants, and when we preserve details).
- Ensure ffs-error stays independent of ffs-ondisk (avoid cyclic deps).
- Update docs to reference the canonical listing in crates/ffs-error/src/lib.rs.

Acceptance:
- No doc section lists a different FfsError variant set than the code.
- FUSE errno mapping is complete and matches chosen policy.

title: Perf: Golden outputs + isomorphism proof protocol for optimizations
description:
Goal: enforce the extreme-software-optimization loop.

Deliverables:
- Define which commands produce golden outputs (JSON reports, fixture parse summaries).
- Store sha256 checksums for goldens.
- Require an isomorphism proof note for each optimization (ordering preserved, tie-breaking unchanged, etc.).

Acceptance:
- There is a repeatable command to verify goldens before/after.
- Optimization PRs cannot "accidentally" change behavior without detection.

title: ext4 semantics: Implement permission/uid/gid + mode mapping details [phased]
description:
Future task: ensure getattr reports correct permission bits and ownership, and FUSE enforces them where appropriate.

Deliverables:
- Map inode mode bits to POSIX file types + permissions.
- Surface uid/gid correctly (including high bits).

Acceptance:
- getattr output matches kernel for a fixture inode set.

title: ffs-types: Checked arithmetic + alignment helpers (block math, offsets)
description:
Goal: centralize all tricky integer math used by on-disk parsing and block mapping.

Deliverables:
- checked_add_bytes(offset, len) -> ByteOffset end
- checked_mul_block(block_nr, block_size) -> ByteOffset
- align_down/align_up helpers with overflow checking
- conversions with explicit error paths (no silent truncation)

Acceptance:
- Unit tests cover overflow/edge cases.
- Call sites in ffs-block/ffs-ondisk/ffs-core prefer these helpers over ad-hoc math.

title: FUSE: Add fuser dependency + skeleton Filesystem impl delegating to FsOps
description:
Goal: make ffs-fuse a thin adapter: kernel FUSE requests -> internal FsOps.

Deliverables:
- Add fuser crate dependency (phase-gated if needed).
- Implement fuser::Filesystem with stubs that call into a boxed FsOps.
- Ensure all errors map through FfsError::to_errno().

Acceptance:
- cargo test passes with fuser integrated.
- The filesystem can be mounted in a no-op mode (returns ENOSYS for unimplemented ops).

title: ext4 semantics: Implement symlink handling (fast/slow) [phased]
description:
Future task: support symlinks.

Deliverables:
- Fast symlinks stored inline in inode i_block.
- Slow symlinks stored as file data.

Acceptance:
- readlink works in harness/FUSE on a fixture symlink.

title: ext4 semantics: Implement extent mapping (ffs-extent) for regular files
description:
Goal: map file logical offsets to physical blocks using the ext4 extent tree.

Deliverables:
- ffs-extent: a function that takes an inode extent root and returns an iterator of (logical_block -> physical_start,len,unwritten?).
- Support depth>0 extent trees by reading extent blocks from disk (requires BlockDevice).
- Provide a read_extent_at(file_block) helper for file reads.

Acceptance:
- Tests cover: leaf-only extents and index+leaf extents.
- Verified on a fixture file with known extents (compare to debugfs stats or golden outputs).

title: Track: Foundations (ffs-types + ffs-error)
description: Define canonical newtypes, parsing primitives, and error model that every other crate depends on.\n\nAcceptance: all normative types (BlockNumber, BlockSize, InodeNumber strategy, TxnId/CommitSeq/Snapshot, ByteOffset, DeviceId, etc.) exist in ffs-types with documented invariants; ffs-error has stable variant set + errno mapping used by FUSE. All other crates use these types (no local duplicates).

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
Why this track is first-class: filesystem bugs love unit confusion (bytes vs blocks) and inconsistent error semantics (silent truncation, wrong errno).

North star:
- ffs-types: strong newtypes + checked arithmetic so invariants are enforced at compile time.
- ffs-error: a stable user-facing error set + errno mapping for FUSE.

If this track is sloppy, every other track becomes untestable and unsafe.

title: Epic: Write Path (alloc + journal + MVCC integration) [future]
description:
Future epic: implement writes in a way that preserves ext4 observable contract but uses FrankenFS internals (MVCC/COW).

Scope:
- allocation (ffs-alloc)
- journal / replay (ffs-journal)
- inode updates, directory updates
- fsync semantics

Acceptance:
- Controlled write workloads run without corruption and with conformance tests.
